user_name:
nicozika
Emirate of Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: Very nice modern hotel in Ginza, walking distance from fish market and well served by about three defferent metro line. We had a room on 14th floor, reasonably big for japanese standards, with all amenities included pijamas! Breakfast was predominantly japanese style, everything we tasted was deliciuos. Staff is amazing and always goes beyond customer expectations. Highly recommended for location and service!

The location was fantastic, the staff were very helpful, friendly beyond belief and professional. The room was small but clean which is normal for Japan. The bed is the best I've ever slept in my life and I have a back issue! The pillows are awesome. The shower was great and the self flush toilet was cool. The breakfast was pricey and not our style of food which is American (we're Canadian actually) so we only ate there when we had early excursions. We stayed five nights and would easily recommend this hotel. When we opened the window blind, there was an office building right across from us with employees working away. I actually found this kind of charismatic and fitting for Japan's culture like overlooking a canal and gondolas in Venice!

Ginza hotels might be costly, and the room size is too efficient (small like any others), yet worth it cuz of location.This particular hotel is very strategic, stations are near by, and there is one right in front of the hotel with elevator access.Staffs are friendly and very helpful. Def will stay here when i get back to Tokyo.One important note, the food in the hotel resto is not good.

Beautiful views of Tokyo. Helpful, friendly staff. The rooms and bathrooms are small but very well configured. Comfortable bed and nice toiletries. We lacked for nothing.The breakfast selection is good for westerners but don't drink the coffee. This is a well designed, modern hotel, well positioned in upmarket Ginza. We enjoyed our time there.
user_name:
Karin M
Knysna, Western Cape, South Africa

review_body: Stayed 2 nights with my husband and 2 year old daughter. Room isn't big but enough to fit our luggages and a cot for my toddler. Bed is comfortable, big tv and a hi tech toilet! Everyone is helpful and they speak English well. Hotel is hip and the area is really nice - very close to shopping (dangerous). Very happy and I highly recommend this hotel.

Very central and perfect for a business trip.The rooms are reasonable size and so the toilets. Very friendly staff,quick checkin and out. The breakfast was sumptuous .I recommend this hotel for business travellers. Iron Fairies Bar is just next door. Probably the best bar in Ginza

Flights from Sydney arrive in Tokyo at 5.00am cannot check into hotel until 3.00pm if you can wait 10 hours with no place to shower or no safe baggage room it a major problem! Rooms small if you are a tall Westerner this hotel is not for you

My husband and myself stayed in Millennium Mitsui for one night and we checked out to stay elsewhere in Tokyo as planned. Its location in central of Ginza is unbeatable. Also the train station is just right outside the hotel. Wifi is good in lobby and room. Bed is very comfortable and we like it that the toilet is separated with the shower area. Some may find the room a little small but we feel that the layout is well planned and it is ok for two.We love the fact that Ginza is a place that really excites us with good food and shopping ! Tsukiji fish market is just a stone throw away. So it is convenient if one would like to wake up early to pay a visit. There are many good restaurants in Ginza worth visiting. It was definitely a good choice to stay in Millenium Mitsui given its good accessibility for transport, shopping , food and some places of interest.

Millenium Mitsui Garden is in an ideal location--walking distance to Tsukiji and Ginza shopping district. There are a lot of great restaurants around the hotel as well as the essentials like a drug store, Starbucks, convenience store, etc... It is also right on two different metro lines that can get you pretty much anywhere in the city. The hotel itself is clean and well-designed. While the rooms are small (as all hotel rooms in Tokyo are), they are very well laid out and quite comfortable. Shiseido toiletries cap off the experience!

Millenium Mitsui Garden Hotel in Ginza has one of the best locations. It sits on top of the Higashi-Ginza Station and allows direct access from Haneda Airport. It is also a 5 minute walk from exit A5 of the Ginza Station. Tsukiji is about an 8 minute walk from the hotel and Ginza Wako building is about 3 blocks away. The rooms are clean and the beds are comfortable enough though a bit on the small side but then, this is Japan! All rooms are on the small side. The food is not great but there are lots of dining options outside the hotel. The staff are very helpful and know how to speak English. All things considered, I think we got our money's worth. I will stay here again and recommend the hotel to friends and family.

Modern hotel in a great location! Rooms are very small but we had an upgraded corner room that had great views over the busy shopping streets below. Comfortable beds. Unusual bathroom setting with sink in the bedroom but 2 separate rooms for toilet and shower/bath area. Location is ideal for shopping as right in the heart of Ginza, close to train station and many cute cafes and restaurants around. The hotel breakfast was very nice and plentiful. Lovely, friendly staff.

When you first walk into hotel lobby, we were impressed, that's where it stopped. Room was small, but very typical size. There was no room service and no mini bar. The wash basin was in the hall as you walked into room. The shower was a very weird set up , no where to put your clothes or towel. You had to wash then dress in the room. For the price of the room, around $320 a night it was very disappointing. Breakfast isn't included, and not a lot to choose from for westerners. I would look elsewhere.

The millennium Mitsui Garden hotel is located in the middle of the Ginza district, a 10 minute walk away from the next train station and directly above the Higashi-Ginza Station underground station. The entrance hall is fancy with a backdrop of changing background light. There are several large reception desks and we only had to wait briefly before greeted. However, having arrived around 10 AM from London, we were slightly disappointed that the earliest check-in is 3 PM. There was even now way we could have a brief shower, but at least we were offered a small changing room. In the afternoon, when we returned to our rooms, we found a large, tidy and stylish hotel room. Our view was down to the main street with large neon advertising’s on the opposite. An excellent view, and certainly giving us the right impression of Tokyo. The bathroom was of outstanding quality, with a fancy toilet (the lid opened automatically when we entered the bathroom) and all the flash controls and other gadgets that are commonly found in Japan. The showroom was separate from the toilet and was large and had a great design. Overall, this was a very nice, urban hotel room, giving us an adequate feeling for Tokyo. Front desk service was very friendly. We did not use the breakfast facility, and instead went to one of the nearby cafes, to enjoy a croissant and a cappuccino in the morning.Overall, this hotel was excellent value for money, considering this central location, the very convenient transport links and the high quality, relatively new interior.

Compact, but not tiny, rooms in this conveniently located hotel in the heart of Ginza. We were out all day but still appreciated a space with room to move. The bathroom was very Japanese but you get used to it. Toiletries were great quality. Bed was on the smaller side by Western standards, but still had a very comfortable sleep. It's a 20 minute walk to Tokyo station so even when we did some day trips on the shinkansen we could easily walk to the station and back. We took a taxi to the station once, when we had all our bags and it was raining fairly heavily. There are taxis right out front (or they will call one for you) and I think it was about $15 Australian dollars to the station. It's a short walk to the fish market which we visited a couple of time. Also, the hotel had a really good map of Ginza and the surrounds which was very useful. Good value for the location but prepare yourself for Japanese (small) rooms.

Neat n clean, very nice view from the hotel room.Great customer service.The hotel is located in Ginza, we usually walk to the shimbashi station , around 3-5 mins away from the hotel. Really a centre to everywhere, but the price is very reasonable.And on our last day, they have shuttle bus to the airport, very convenience.

Pluses: Fantastic location above subway stop, and one block from the main shopping areas of Ginza. Super well maintained modern comfortable hotel with comfortable beds. Small rooms though.Minuses: Depending on the direction of your room, the view is directly onto the rooftop air conditioning units etc. The Superior double rooms seem smaller than the regular double rooms. Just has a better view?

The hotel was very clean and in an excellent location. It is very close to several subways, although if you only have a Japan Rail Pass (as we did when we first arrived), and you're arriving by train, you'll need to go to Yurakucho Station and walk from there. It's under 10 minutes and a very easy walk. As with all Japanese stations, it's important that you know which exit to take, so in this case, take the exit from Yurakucho that has Starbucks on the corner and turn right, go straight ahead past the fruit shop, then past Duo and head for the huge Lumine sign. Go through the passageway into the main street - this is the street that the hotel is in. Turn left and you'll see in the distance a tall building with Mitsukoshi on it - the hotel is opposite this building.When our JR Pass ran out, we then bought a Suica Pass (or you can buy a Pasmo, same thing) to cover the subway/metro lines - it will cost 500 Yen but this is only a deposit and you can cash it in at the airport as you leave (at the JR office there). You then put money on the Suica Pass, exactly the same as an Oyster Card in London. Hint - to get to Haneda Airport from Yurakucho, go two stations to Hamametsucho and then take the monorail straight to the airport. The total cost on your Suica Pass will be 630 Yen so make sure that you have this amount still on your Pass. If you still have a Japan Rail Pass, you can get right from Yurakucho to Hamametsucho and then the monorail to the airport, all on the JR Pass. You will forfeit any outstanding credit on your Suica Pass, so try to run it down on your last few days by only adding small amounts to it as you need it.The hotel is an easy and interesting walk to the Palace, Tokyo Station and all around Ginza which is wonderful in itself. We were given great maps of Tokyo and Ginza by the hotel staff who were very helpful. There are hundreds of places to eat within 10 minutes of the hotel - no shortage there!The hotel staff gave us a map of the hop-on-hop-off bus and showed us its starting point for all three routes, just the other side of Yurakucho Station - easy to walk there too. There are two different types of hop-on-hop-off bus, one that you can actually get on and off, and one that just does the routes without stopping, so make sure that you buy tickets for the right one. The cost for the one that stops was 3,500 Yen, covering all three routes. You buy the tickets at the bus stop.

We had a pleasant 5 days stay at this hotel. The location in the centre of Tokyo and a minut from the subway is great for exploring Tokyo. Comfortable and clean rooms. Only downside is the breakfast. The selection for a Western/ European tourist is simply too limited for the price of 2550 Yen per person. Too narrow selection of cereals, fresh fruit and bread. No European style omelette. We just went for breakfast once. Great selection of cafes that serve breakfast in the neighbourhood.

We began our vacation in Japan by staying in this hotel in the Ginza Neighborhood of Tokyo. The location is great- easily accessible by many subway lines, we arrived easily the first day. You are across the street from the Kabukiza Theatre and a ten minute walk from the Tsukiji Fish Market ( a must see when in Tokyo). The staff is friendly and the rooms are very clean. The rooms are small by western standards, but very comfortable. The neighborhood is busy during the day and extremely quiet at night- which makes it difficult to find a place to eat after 8 or 9 pm. We also found it difficult to find breakfast places (hotel breakfast can be expensive)- note that most places open around 9 or 10am. There is a Denny's a few blocks away or a Starbucks nearby that open early. Would definitely go back to the same hotel if I visit Tokyo in the future.

This modern, chic hotel is quite comfortable and conventiently located in the heart of Ginza. We spent our first night in Tokyo here and enjoyed the wealth of eating places nearby, being steps from a subway stop, across the street from a kabuki theatre, near name brand shopping and department stores and the ultra modern lobby with traditional touches -- a rock garden and an enormous vase of cherry blooms. The front desk seemed to have difficulty conveying a message to our friends who were arriving the same night but at a different time. Other than this, our stay was super and I'd definitely stay here again but book as early as possible to get a good rate.

Extremely well located in downtown Tokyo across the street from Mitsukoshi Ginza and within walking distance of Tsukiji and the Imperial Palace grounds. Extremely friendly and helpful desk staff, who are happy to assist with both receptionist and concierge duties. Modern building, with Japanese-sized but efficiently designed rooms. Adequate breakfast served in the downstairs restaurant ($25/person). Only complaint is the awful pillows, apparently stolen from the Spanish Inquisition.

I checked in here and had a comfortable check in. Location is excellent as only 20 meters from Mitsukoshi Department store and is in heart of Ginza. Room was new, however tight on size. I entered the toilet which was build to a minimum acceptable size. If you were a large westerner or any race person the toilet would annoy you. Disappointingly I saw 2 black curly pubic hairs in the corner of the toilet room. Seems cleaner had not vacuumed well. That disgusted me. Went shopping..came back at 10 pm after dinner and crashed. I'm 184 cms and my feet were right hard at the bed bottom. Could not believe it, however they had cut on bed size. Fine for anyone short but otherwise terrible. The beds were rock hard too. I paid JPY 26,000 a night and had 2 nights. This was ok if you had paid JPY 12,000 a night which is what these type of hotels used to be before the Japan tourist numbers greatly increased by Chinese and other nationalities people traveling in large numbers to Japan as visa constraints were released in the last couple of years. I checked out the next morning. They politely refunded the next night. I even met another guy from Germany complaining about same bed issues on way down in elevator..seesm they maximised number of rooms by reducing size. I found its owned by the Kwek family (CDL Singapore and Millennium Hilton) , yet operated by Mitsui. Typical of the Kweks to cut corners there. Ironically I heard later from a friend that teh Kweks only stay at the Peninsula Tokyo when visit. Thats says alot about their own hotel! Another issue on this hotel is that its hard to geta cab..no concierge eithe rot help with baggage. Its totally geared towards cheaper tourists.I promptly moved to the Imperial Hotel in Ginza..paid over twice the cost, yet got 100% excellent service and access to an excellent room with a very comfortable bed, excellent in-house dining too. Will not make the mistake to save and suffer by staying at the Millennium Ginza again. Its ok for tourists on a budget, yet it is not budget pricing!

This is an excellent hotel with a great location right next to a subway station in Ginza. Rooms are small but very modern and reasonably priced. There is only one restaurant but there are lots of things very close by. Would definitely stay here again.

I love this hotel for its location but not happy about the room size. Room size is so small and no bell service! We have to take our own luggages which i am abit surprised for a 4 stars hotel?New hotel everything is clean. Opposite of the hotel you will get to access to Mitsukoshi mall. Tsukiji market is about 15minutes walk. I have been staying in this hotel for 2 occasions in year 2015. WIll return again in April 2016. Pay more for a Corner room. But I think Corner room only comes in Twin Beds.

Stayed for 4 nights overall experience is good all though the price of millennium mitsui considered not cheap at all, room is clean n neat best thing is if u r taking train from haneda airport drop at higashi Ginza station it only take 35min to reach & there is ice making room in e hotel but not sure does it locate in every floor is very convenient for pple like me who always drink cold drink. about 10min walk to fish market along the way u will pass by fruit shop & u can get the cantaloupe really worth to try it out cost round 2-3000 yan if u dun mind the hassle to bring back to sg & tat a ramen restaurant just next to the hotel.....for late night time tat 24hr sushi shop n Don k mall to roam around instate of take cab to other pla for supper, coz cab is very costly in Tokyo a good choice hotel if u on a loose budget. last is for those who first time travel to japan remember to bring along passport for tax rebate at e shop counter when ever u done the shopping...dun think airport have tax refund counter.

The hotel is in a very convenient location if you are interested in shopping or eating fine Japanese food. The restaurants at Ginza are pricy, but Tsukiji is only about 10 min walk. Try sushi for breakfast. The hotel is above the Higashi-Ginza station. The elevator going down into the station is right outside the hotel. There are relatively convenient connections to the Narita and Haneda airports. Though the train ride takes longer than some of the express trains, it is much faster and cheaper than going to Tokyo or Ueno stations to transfer to an express train. Of course, during rush hour you might want a reserved seat. The rooms are elegant and comfortable. Those facing away from the street are very quiet. I did not experience the other side, but imagine that Ginza goes to sleep late. The down side is the uncouth clientele from near abroad, who visit Ginza for shopping.

We stayed in the Millennium Mitsui Garden for 4 nights in February aiming for easy strolling around the areas around Ginza. The hotel is located just two minutes walk from the Chuo Dori Mitsukoshi department store junction. Hotel room is clean with modern tasteful deco, a wardrobe, well designed bath and effective sound proof to keep noise away amid the central location. Hotel staff are professional and friendly with assisting location access and cheerful greetings. Check in and check out were just efficient. There is a hotel restaurant at the basement and we spotted that it looked like a popular place however we didn't have a chance to be a patron in there. The walk to the Yurakucho JR station is approximately 13 minutes with luggage. And it took 15 minutes by walk to the Tsukiji fish market.

Hotel is conveniently locared, there's a metro station exit almost right next to its entrance. It's just a block away from the busiest part of Ginza, and about 10 mins walk to Tsujiki fisk market. A good base to tour around Toyko. Staff were friendly and helpful.However, airport limousine don't stop here. The nearest stop was Marriott Courtyard, which was 5,-10 mins away, depending on if one's carrying heavy luggages.Even so, still prefer this to Marriott Courtyard as there were many eateries nearby the Millennium and the deco was more modern here.

Only complaint is the tiny rooms! Don't get me wrong, its well equipped and everything, including the service was more than satisfactory, but its just sooo small (about 150sqft). Can't beat the location though, right opposite Mitsukoshi, and within walking distance to countless restaurants, high end shops, subway station and the kabuki theatre.

This Ginza hotel is less than a 5 minute walk from the 4-chome central crossing of Ginza, with many restaurants, department stores and specialty shops in easy walking distance. The Tokyo metro stops immediately outside the hotel. If you take the limo bus from Narita, go to the Marriott Courtyard Ginza, which is a 3 minute walk. Just continue in the direction the bus was heading and turn left at the second corner, and you are at the Millennium. The rooms are large for Tokyo, and in-room facilities are very good. All in all, good value for money, and good location. I would stay here again any time I am in Tokyo.
user_name:
Alan B
New York City, New York

review_body: I booked a room for my boyfriend's birthday trip from 18-23 Feb, I requested a birthday cake thru email and ask them to deliver on the 20th Feb at 00:00, they delivered the cake very on time and with a friendly smile. The recommendation of restaurant was excellent!!! Thank you so much for the staff who has helped me to organised everything for my boyfriend, I really appreciate your help :)

Millennium Mitsui Garden Hotel Tokyo is in Central Ginza and surrounded by many good restaurants and cafes.Ginza station is 5 mins walk while there is a nearer station by the hotel in less than a minute walk.Location is good to airport as the stop is about 5-8 mins walk .

Absolutely love this hotel, would definitely stay here again if we're in Tokyo. Great location, has access to several subway lines, walking distance to the fish market. The staff here were amazing, very helpful, showed us all the nice restaurants nearby, just made our trip so much more convenient knowing we could go to them with any question as Tokyo can be a bit confusing sometimes. The hotel is at a reasonable price for its location and amenities. Given the size of hotels normally are in Tokyo, this hotel actually has a decently sized room, so it was very comfortable.

After living in Japan for over a year and visiting several times before that, I've stayed in all types of hotels, ryokans, and AirBNB places, and this one exceeds most! The best part is the access-an elevator directly from Higashi-Ginza station brings you to the front door, and only one train brings you from Shinagawa to Higashi-Ginza (Keikyu line). Anyone with luggage or small children (we had both) will appreciate this. Our room was beautiful and large for Tokyo, we were able to easily fit a crib in for our baby and also have our two year old stay with us.

The hotel is just across Mitsukoshi Department store in Ginza. Ginza is my favorite area to stay when I'm in Tokyo. The rooms are very spacious unlike the regular Tokyo standards and the bathroom is very clean and well appointed. I just wish they would add more english TV channels so in case the guests decide to stay in the rooms early, there would be a some shows to watch.

I guess I should start with saying that Tokyo is one of my favourite cities in the world and this was our 4th stay. It was also our second stay at the Millennium Mitsui Garden Hotel and it won't be our last. We love the location - right in the heart of Ginza - so if you love high end shopping, or even just window shopping it's the place to be. The multi lingual staff are helpful, efficient and make the stay a pleasure. The young lady who checked us in was kind enough to translate a restaurant booking and made sure that we understood it all and provided a map and directions.Our room this time did not have a view - but if you are staying in Ginza - you should really only be using your room to sleep in. You have so many choices when it comes to eating. Near Yuracucho station (a 5-10 minute walk) under the railway lines are loads of yakatori restaurants. The major department stores all have restaurants on the top floors and massive food halls where you can pick up anything from sandwiches to sushi - good if you are on a budget.Across the road is the Kabuki theatre, Mitukoshi department store and you are also on top of top metro stations.

Arrived at Tokyo as a group in rainy day, when we came in to this hotel, straight away reception lady wipe the water off of my luggage and offer us 10 or 12 umbrella to lend. This kind of reception is amazing. Sorry i didnt catch her name.Check-in was smooth and quick. Room is very good, modern and very very clean. Everything works out perfectly. I like the shower, got a nice pressure and very accurate water temp. Breakfast was also good, got everything that i want.No need to say about the location, it literally at the heart of ginza. I stayed at Mitsui Garden Ginza Premiere before, but definitely will consider this hotel in the future. Best value for the money.

We had a wonderful time staying here and spending time in Tokyo. It is amazingly neat & uncluttered for such a big city. The politeness of everyone is infectious. I can't wait to go back to beautiful Tokyo. Ginza is the best location.

Stayed here for 6 nights on a recent business trip. Big modern and clean rooms. Good bed and an automatic toilet. The staff are very friendly and attentive. There is a good restaurant in the basement. Located just off the Ginza main shopping area with a metro stop close by and a 10 minute walk to Tokyo station. One issue, it hasn't a bar or a seating area, you cant really sit in the restaurant for a meeting. Big lobby without real seats, very odd.

The location is good if you want t got to Tsukiji fish market.I want to complaint about the pricing! We booked one month ago with USD400/night for twin room. We found from Tripadvisor again at the date of chackin and it was only USD220. We like this place but will try to book as close as check in day next time。

We stayed with 2 nights in a Central double- basically this means you have no view and face a brick wall - which for us was fine as we would be out and about and we wanted a quiet room. The rooms appointment was excellent... everything you could need (even a mirror with electric socket and a separate full length mirror -- which for a girl both are essential but often lacking!). There is plenty about the fab toilet... the shower is also roomy and great with 2 shower heads (rain and extendable). You get slippers and pyjamas and the usually toiletries. There is free wifi. The staff were friendly and efficient. The location is great for getting out and about, located right by the A1 exit Higashi-Ginza on the Hibiya line or a 5-10 min walk from Ginza (Marunouchi, Hibiya and Ginza metro lines). You can go direct from Haneda Airport to Higashi-Ginza, takes 30 mins.

Overall the hotel was conveniently located to subway access, and if you're worried about navigating the subway, don't be, it's amazing and puts Toronto TTC to shame. The staff weren't as friendly as we would have expected, and the language barrier was a non issue. They seemed reluctant to make recommendations on places to eat, and struggled with directions. To be fair, we had the trip pretty well planned out and had addresses for most places we wanted to go, you just couldn't rely on the hotel staff to help get you there. Rings true to the proximity to the Ginza shopping district, however for the most part, unless you are aware of a very specific night spot, this area gets very quiet by around 10pm. The hotel was otherwise beautiful, exactly as expected. We stayed for 2 nights, and the room was exactly what we needed after the 13 hour flight and commute from the airport.

I loved this hotel and from the pictures of the other guests, I see they liked the same we did. We stayed ten nights here. Wouldn't stay anywhere else. This is the best area and the best hotel. Modern, too services. Modern, well designed rooms. Great service, they speak English and the best you have subway station outside the hotel. Wonderful.

The sub-way station that comes from Narita and Haneda airport is literally downstairs. In one of the most beautiful zones of Tokyo. Walking distance to the Tsukiji market. The modern great taste rooms have top services with excellent room distribution. Great taste and the unique Japanese service. The staff has the best service attitude. They speak English and help you the best way they can. I would defensively come back here every time I come back to Tokyo. Safe havens are necessary, specially if you want the occidental touch in Asia.

Over the years we have stayed at 5 hotels in the Tokyo Ginza area all very near the department stores. This hotel is the best overall. I booked 2 rooms corner twin (97,400Y) and superior double (71,300Y) both for 4 nights. My wife and I stayed in the corner twin which at first seemed small because we couldn't set up 2 medium suitcases. However once we got this resolved we found the room to be very comfortable. Our very large window facing the Mitsukoshi Department store annex was very nice. The room had a sitting area facing this window so we could watch the hustle & bustle below. We were on the fifth floor so my wife could even see the type of clothing being worn.The modern room had everything one would need. I did not expect in room free wifi but it was included. However do your video phone calls very early or later in the day. We had some issues with bandwidth between 7 and 10 in the morning. Another pleasant surprise was a Nespresso machine with 6 free capsules filled each morning. The toilet was great with auto flush. However I would prefer that the toilet cover did not automatically lift each time we walked by the toilet area. We resorted to closing the door.My sister stayed in the superior double. This queen room was a lot smaller then our room however the square shape made it easier to organize. I booked the room for 2 persons because at some hotels a single person room is different. She loved her room even with the size and without much of a view. Also this room did not have a Nespresso machine but she just came to our room for morning coffee. And both Mitsukoshi and Matsuya department stores sell Nespresso capsules.For the Ginza area the room charges in JPY are exceptional. However I did book 8 months in advance through booking.com. We will stay at this hotel for future trips especially if their prices stay competitive. And I hope the US dollar buys as much yen as this trip!

Hotel is in a great location in Ginza, walking distance to some great bard, restaurants and plenty of fantastic shopping. The only set back for us that the rooms were tiny, not enough to fit two people comfortable and that we were allocated a smoking room, when we are really NOT smokers. we left after 5 days covered in smoke unfortunately. the staff are very friendly and some more versed in English than others. There is a metro stop - Higoshi Ginza, literally underneath the hotel - so it is fantastic for getting around anywhere else in Tokyo.

My wife, the younger sister and I stayed here for 2 nights. We all rated highly of this hotel in Ginza.Location and Surroundings: There is an elevator to the Higashi-Ginza subway station. The Toei Asakusa line will connect you to Tokyo Skytree, Odaiba and Shimbashi (a major transfer station to Yamanote line and Yokohama a major plus for JR Rail Pass holders). There are also many convenient stores within minutes of the hotel. Taxis are also always available in front of the hotel.Room: We had 3 people in our group, so we got the corner triple bed room which was spacious considering it was Tokyo. Shower was the best we had in Japan so far. The washlet was a highly advanced one as well. Bed was super comfy and I even snored on one of the nights.Staff: We want to give a special mention to one of the staff member, Takahashi-san who is a trainee at the hotel. My wife was suffering from a health condition and needed to consult a doctor. We realized that we would face difficulties in communication and getting a doctor's appointment. Even though she was a trainee, Takahashi-san went above and beyond to look for a English speaking doctor (or with translator service) when we explained our situation to her. Her command of English was good as well. Takahashi-san managed to secure an appointment at a nearby international hospital (St. Luke International Hospital) and my wife got her consultation and was feeling better. We would like to express our utmost gratitute to Takahashi-san for her efforts (Domo arigatou gozaimasu Takahashi-san!).

This is an excellent option for Ginza visitors.The rooms are not huge (they are not anywhere in Ginza) but they are modern, well put together with the highlight being that the toilette seat lifts itself as soon as one walks into the toilet. Everything functions well, and efficient.Location: You are literally in the middle of Ginza and next to several subway stations, so both location and transport needs are looked after.Staff speak good English (not a given in Japan) and are helpful and attentive.The lobby is modern and pleasant. Wifi was free and of excellent quality.I highly recommend this property for leisure and business travelers. Good rooms, modern and chic ambience, and top location.

First impressions, very clean and efficient in lobby, busy but all organized by the very friendly staff. Our rooms were not too small but contained everything you could possibly want or need, slippers, pjs, hairdryer, bidet in toilet, compact separate bath area with tub and shower....Concierge always willing to help. Only 10 mins walk to the Tsujiki Fish Market for breakfast! Even closer to get to the main shopping area with Mitsukoshi being right across the hotel. In Room Massage service until late at night, perfect for tired bodies!

Our family of six had three rooms for 4 nights as a stop over on our way back from skiing in Hirafu (Niseko). The hotel is in a great location and has easy access to trains, buses and taxi and a short walk to lots of restaurants and bars. The hotel itself is clear and the rooms are a standard size for Japan, there is a breakfast buffet which is ok however you need to get there early as the food gets cold due to people leaving the tops of everything. Price range is in the mid range and the shopping is good but it is the expensive end of town so do not expect many deals and you may need to go elsewhere if you have teenagers ( as we did) .

The location of this hotel is fantastic, it's directly across from Mitsukoshi department store. We stayed here for only 1 night in transit before flying back home and this is our 6th visit to Japan. The hotel location and cleanliness is excellent, however, there's a lack of service and warm hospitality by the front reception when we checked in. The hotel when we stayed had high volume of traffic and perhaps they were overworked and exhausted? I've had much better service elsewhere and would return to this hotel only for it's prime location and proximity to many great restaurants.

This was our 1st hotel upon arriving in Japan and it was perfect for what we were looking for. Efficient, small but clean room, above average but nothing extra ordinary.Hotel rooms in Tokyo are small and so was ours. Bed was very very comfy and excellent bedlinnen. The breakfast buffet was the best of what we encountered during our travels through Japan, albeit a bit expensive. Would recommend.

I was in Tokyo for a 5 day stretch in late November. Tokyo was, quite literally, fully booked. I managed to get what seemed to be the last corner room available at the Millennium Mitsui (I had planned on staying at the Grand Hyatt butit was full).Anyhow, I was very pleasantly surprised. Rooms were clean and nice. Staff was friendly and helpful. The location turns out to be almost perfect - it has a subway station entrance 30 feet or so from the front door - that gets you onto two of the main lines I use so extremely convenient. Having Mitsukoshi across the street with its food hall was also a nice bonus for quick lunch grabs.The only downside is the room wasn't exactly huge but hey its Tokyo. I also found it a bit more expensive that I had planned but literally that particular week everything was booked and prices were higher. Looking now the rates are half what I paid and at the price the place is a screaming steal.Definitely would stay again.

This hotel is excellently located just outside the elevator exit A1 at Higashi-Ginza station. It was an easy 30 minute journey from Haneda International Airport terminal on a direct train that runs every 20 mins at :14, :34 or :54 past the hour. There are other trains available, but require a change. It's also just a few minutes walk from A5 exit Ginza station. I was immediately impressed by this modern hotel. Check in was easy, lift access was secure with key card only. I had a superior double room on the 11th floor. I had a good view of the Kabuki theatre from the room. I found the room to be super clean, comfortable and quiet. Yes, the room was small, but the layout made it feel larger than it was because it was a very practical layout. The wardrobe area, although open, had additional baskets for easy storage of smaller items. I was able to use the luggage stand in the wardrobe to house my suitcase. The only downside to this was that it blocked access to the safe. But this way, I could still hang clothes and have full run of the room. The room was well lit and temperature comfortably thermostat controlled. The bed was so comfortable with a choice of pillows. The duvet was so soft and fluffy and all made for excellent nights sleep. Pyjamas and slippers were provided also.Coffee and tea making facilities were available along with a near silent kettle above the refrigerator that contained complimentary water. The sink area was opposite a shower/bath room and a separate toilet and this worked out to be very practical. The sink was well lit, was well stocked with amenities - Shiseido facial care, shower caps and a hairdryer in the drawer that could be plugged in at the sink area for access to the mirror. The shower room had a separate bath tub, which was joyously deep, but the shower was powerful and water drained away quickly. And so to the toilet. It seems odd to talk about this, but it truly is magical. As soon as you slide open the door, the toilet lid pops up in anticipation. The seat is always heated and you have full bidet and drying facilities as the push of a button. Truly revolutionary. And even for the men, there's a button that lifts the toilet seat up and down to save touching the seat at all! Somehow the convenience was amazing. Overall, a perfect stay. A really well equipped room that was quiet, comfortable and clean. Free wifi also. The staff were friendly and the location was amazing. Highly recommended!

Love this hotel. The staff are amazingly helpful, super friendly, and very easy to communicate in English with. Great location, walking distance to all amenities and subway/trains. Underground Subway access right outside hotel. Rooms are modern and very clean, not massive but good in Japan terms and have everything you could need. Highly recommend this hotel if you're looking for great accommodation in Tokyo at a good price. Very very happy we stayed here.

I stayed in the Millennium Mitsui Garden in December, 2015. The Hotel is not grandiose alike the Ritz Carlton & Conrad Hotels, which are located (inconveniently) in the business district, however, the hotel features a modern decor, excellent service and an exceptional location for tourists. The rooms are decently sized, particularly in light of the usual Japanese standard. They are comfortable and luxuriously appointed.In light of the Comfort, Service and Convenience... I will definitely stay in this Hotel when I return.An excellent stay.

I've stayed in this hotel for 5 days and the overall experience was ok.The first impression was really bad since the staff of the hotel almost don't speak english so like always you have difficulties to explain basic things. I didn't like that they asked us to pay for the hotel, without showing us the room. I said that i wanted to pay in the end of the stay because i didn't know if i pay in cash or with a credit card, they said that i couldn't do that. Than i said that i wanted to see the room before paying, they also said it was not possible. I don't understand why in a 4star hotel they don't show the room or don't let pay in the end of the stay since they had a credit card a a guarantee...???however we paid and we got a key. the room was on the 11th floor and it was ok. It was said that it had 20 square meters, but it was smaller. The room does not have a closet, plus the bathroom is separated by window glass from the bed. The lavatory is in the middle of the room...I know that this is the style of the hotel so im not implying on the design but in general its strange. The bed was too hard, the sleep quality was average.I like the view from the window: the main street. Location is good, near to everything, near to tokyo station. though we took a taxi from there to the hotel around 1000yens. be aware that the taxi drivers in front of the hotel are rude, since they are waiting for tourists to take them to the airports, and we just took a taxi to tokyo station.The room had complimentary water, coffee tea.Good bathroom accessories, creams, shampoo, brush etc...Would not stay in this hotel again, because of the size of the room, we had to put our luggages in the bathroom since it didn't fit in the room. The people travelling with children be aware that baby carriage does not fit in the room. The ppl in the room next to us had it outside as well as the baby bed.

We stayed at this hotel in early January 2016. We had two rooms next to each other. We arrived at the hotel at 2:49 pm in the afternoon, and one of the rooms was not even ready yet (the check-in time is 3 pm). Even worse, when we walked in the room, it was so dirty on the ground. We saw dirty inks, and hair on the ground. We need to ask them to clean up the room again!!! This is totally not acceptable given the price they charged. Also, when we checked in, the staff had no smile at all, and was rude! We had been at japan more than 20 times, and this is the worst experience so far.

I struggled to get a hotel over Christmas so ended up here. Perfect location on the Ginza line. Room was clean and modern and in good condition (hotel a year or so old) breakfast wasn't included but 2500 each - a buffet that was ok. View was pretty ugly from the 11th floor side street but quiet with the window closed. No noise from guests who were mostly Chinese. Recommend finding a nearby noodle shop in Ginza station Kagari Echita Fit -just just outside the Marunouchi Line wicket (a long walk from the Ginza Line).

This the the best hip hotel in Tokyo. The location is more than five stars as right outside the subway. The room is not do big but good enough for a family stay there. The front desk services just perfect and the room is very so beautiful. It got all necessity there.

I chose to stay at this hotel because of its location. It doesn't get better than this. The hotel is right in the center of Ginza, among many shops and opposite Mitsukoshi department stores where you can find all types of food and supermarket. Tokyo Metro is a few minutes walk depending which Line you are taking. It's also very convenient to walk to the Fish Market (10 min).The hotel looks brand new and very well kept. The room is quite small but that is to be expected for Tokyo Standard. But the layout of the room is quite good so you don't feel cramp like some other places.If you like to stay in Ginza area, this is THE hotel to stay in.

Among all the hotels we have stayed in Tokyo, this rates as one of the best. We are a family of 3, including a teen aged son, and the triple-corner room that we had was spacious and very comfortable. The hotel itself was located in a very convenient location, with the entrance to Higashi-Ginza station (Asakusa and Hibiya lines) just out the main door and the one to Ginza station ((Marumouchi and Ginza lines) just a short walk down the street. Tsukiji fish market is just a 10 minute walk away and tons of shopping and food all around. We have stayed here on two occasions and will be staying here again when we come to Tokyo again.. Ichi ban!!!!

Newish (2014) 14 story hotel in Ginza. Excellent location for stores, places to eat and transportation.It’s a 900 – 1,200 yen cab ride from Tokyo station (depending upon traffic) and above 2 subway lines (Higashi – Ginza station for the Asakusa and Hibiya lines). If you take the Narita Airport Limousine bus the nearest stop is 2 blocks away at the Courtyard Tokyo Ginza Hotel.Average sized room for Tokyo but new and very well equipped. The room seemed larger due to high ceilings and 0ne large 6 X 6’ window. Very large bath tub was a treat.Very quiet. Nice bed and pillows. Large flat screen TV but no English channels.

This is one hotel I will not hesitate to recommend to anyone travelling in Tokyo. Why? 1. Location: smack in Ginza, it was very easy for us to get to places we wanted to get to: E.g. Tsukiji market (1 stop by subway), Disneyland (30 min by JR line to Maihama)2. Suitable for all ages. Our party of 6 ranged from 10 to 74 year olds. We stayed 4 nights in the hotel. 3. A good mix of Japanese and Western breakfast. We made the effort to eat mainly the Japanese food since we were in Japan and the food was tasty. 4. Honesty of staff: this is what impressed me most. I left my cosmetics in the room when I checked out. When I emailed the hotel only 3 days later, they informed me they did have my items. They packaged it very securely (bubble wrapped) and sent it to my address in Japan at that time at my expense. What more can I say about their service other than EXCELLENT!

Great location in ginza but beware there are 2 similar named hotels.Easy walk to the bright lights of ginza and tokyo station is only 25 minutesGet the airport limosine bus from tokyo narita, last stop is fot this hotel

The hotel is located at the heart of Ginza and is an extremely comfortable stay. Everything from the coffee machine to the complimentary night suits, speaks of luxury. We could borrow their umbrellas during the day which was very helpful since we came unprepared for so much rain. Overall an excellent stay. The only down side was that their breakfast was always too long a wait so we could never experience it. I know the automated toilets are a norm in Japan but the Toto washlet installed here was just amazing. If you come from where I do, an automated toilet is true luxury and comfort. About the staff present, there is no beating the Japanese hospitality and the staff at Millennium Mitsui Garden lived up to it. They were always warm and helped us locate great restaurants to eat at. Overall, nothing to complain about this hotel, just blindly go for it and enjoy.

The hotel is a 10 minute walk from Tokyo station, which is on the Narita Express from the airport. Ginza is a great location with lots of shops, bars and restaurants. It's also very close to all the sight seeing areas. All the staff were very welcoming & knowledgeable. The room was small but it was perfectly formed with shiseido toiletries. The loo was a joy with its heated seat & various bidet settings. The wet room shower & bathwere top quality. Breakfast is very good value for money with Japanese & Western choices; we went for both. Thank you to all the team,we loved our stay and we loved Tokyo.

review_body: First time in Japan & picked this one based on ratings & location. Paid about $250 USD a night not including breakfast. Hotel is hip and modern, quiet, polite and well located. Observations:English at check-in not really well understood but what else is new?The robotic toilet with 8 control buttons had me very confused for a while but I got the hang of it. The motion sensor that raises the lid as you walk by made my trip.Room & beds good with great neon-lit views of Tokyo hurly-burly.You must go around the corner to the FUKUMIMI Yakitori bar- fun, festive, wacky organ meats grilled on bamboo skewers and other joys to be had. Awesome.Tsukiji fish market a walkable distance away- Free attraction you can just walk around for hours marveling at the menagerie of sea creatures being processed and shipped. More fun than it sounds- the famous tuna auctions are a separate deal-see other reviews.Hamarikyu Gardens also walkable distance- pleasant park with rich history & audio GPS tours.Breakfast was DYNOMITE! Insane variety for a smaller business hotel- If you can find breakfast in the States that has cured pork, smoked fish, vegtable soup, scrambled eggs, a chocolate fondue fountain, yogurt, lychee fruit, congee, pastries, acerola juice, bacon, green mustard-kiwi-banana shakes, tapioca, cappuccino, cheese, fresh bread, cereal etc. all in one place, message me.WINNER

This is an extremely functional and practical hotel. On the small side but in Tokyo, that's to be expected. Its location is superb. The hotel is about 10 minutes away from Tsukiji fish market, and the elevator to the Higashi-Ginza train station is literally in front of the main entrance. Ginza shopping district is a stone's throw away with large departmental stores like Mitsukuoshi about 5 minutes walk.

Central of the city. Very near to Tsukiji market and the imperial palace. Plenty of shopping centers around for Windows shoppers. Room are small but compact. There are also many transport options to Haneda airport. It's also 5 train stations away from the night spot Roppongi.

The Millenium Mitsui Garden Hotel Ginza is an excellent example of a four-star minimalist boutique hotel which combines up-to-date clever design, good management, and a great location. Mitsui Garden Hotels are a well-known Japanese hotel group; Millenium is a reputable Singapore-based international property group for which this hotel is their entry into the Japanese market.Japanese hotel rooms generally are known for being small. At about 26 square meters, the rooms in this hotel nominally are at the small end of the scale. However, such care has been given to efficient layout and fitout of the rooms that we did not feel unduly cramped.• Location and access: centrally located in the Ginza shopping district, with elevator access to a subway station (Higashi-Ginza) right outside the front door. It takes about half an hour to reach the hotel from Haneda International Airport by subway via the Keikyu-Kuko and Asakusa lines; or about an hour and a quarter from Narita via the Narita Skyaccess and Asakusa lines. Look for the A1 exit from the Higashi-Ginza station concourse, take the elevator (not the stairs if you have baggage) from the end of a short (about 50m) passage, turn sharp left at ground level, and you are at the hotel entrance. Getting around after checking in is very easy too—either via the multi-operator Tokyo subway system (our subway and walking navigation tool was Google Maps on an iPad equipped with a prepaid nano-SIM card from Bic Camera Yurakucho branch (11 mins walk). The hotel is surrounded by fashion stores and dozens of dining-out options. Tsukiji Market is 9 mins (750m) away; the principal Kabuki theatre of Tokyo, the Kabuki-za, only 3mins (230m) walk. We found it necessary to take a cab (from the rank at the hotel entrance) only once, to carry us and our baggage in comfort to board Shinkansen services at the main Tokyo Station, 1.6km away.• Room fittings: The bathroom is Japanese-style, with a deep sit-up bathtub and shower with both fixed and handheld heads. The single vanity/washbasin is cleverly located in the entry way to make maximum use of minimal room space. The quality tapware is by Hansgrohe (German). The toilet (separate from bathroom) is one of the latest Japanese electronic bidet toilets by Toto with seat warming and adjustable jet gadgetry. The large late model flat-screen TV is Panasonic. The window has a sheer blind for privacy while admitting light; and a blackout blind that blocks light better than most we have seen in any hotel anywhere. Combined with excellent soundproofing (no noticeable street noise despite the busy area) this makes for a good rest. A small refrigerator is left unstocked (no mini-bar) for guests’ own purchases. A quality range of toiletries, including shower caps, shampoo and conditioner, toothbrushes, and liquid soap is provided. • Internet: free and fast for multiple devices. Wi-fi and Ethernet cable connection available.• Power outlets: The room has a good number and distribution of unearthed parallel 2-pin Japanese outlets (Type A) supplying the local 100 V 50 Hz mains power—but only two three-pin grounded outlets (Type B), one inconveniently placed above the washbasin, and the other at floor level just inside the entry door.• Television programs: mostly Japanese, apart from a cut-down version for Japan of CNN. A very poor selection for international travellers, but we did not come to Tokyo to watch television anyway.• Restaurant: had one unimpressive meal at the Niko restaurant in the hotel basement, and did not take a breakfast-included option. This is not a problem: the hotel is located in one of the best districts of one of the best cities of the world for eating out.• Note: this is not the similarly named Mitsui Garden Hotel Ginza Premier, a nearby but less conveniently located hotel in an office tower about 500m southwest.• Overall: Millenium Mitsui Garden Hotel Ginza is a clean, quiet, modern, well-appointed hotel with exceptional ease of walking access to the best shopping of the Ginza district and for sightseeing elsewhere in Tokyo via the subway system.

Stayed here two weeks ago. The hotel is brand spanking new and you can tell. The lobby is very cool and the bathtub was extremely clean. Rooms are on the smaller side but that's to be expected in any major city. Two of us with 1 large and 1 carry on suitcase managed to maneuver around each other just fine. The selling point, however, is that it's only a 9 minute walk to the fish market and very close to the subway. The Shisedo skin products were an added bonus and the shower was phenomenal. The only weird thing was that they ask you to pay when checking in. Tip: there is a great noodle place right across the street (we got in at 6 pm after a 14 hr flight so we just wanted something quick), we then woke up at 2 am and walked over to the fish market for the tuna auction and some great sushi at Sushi Daiwa.

review_body: The rooms are spacious considering the prime location right next to the subway. The decor is modern. Service is excellent. Tip top fittings in the toilet. Shiseido lotions?! And price is very reasonable. Considered cheaper than most hotels in the area. And it doesn't mean they are not good.

This was the first of three hotels we enjoyed in Japan and we would thoroughly recommend it for anybody spending a few touristic nights in the capital. The location was just right for us, near the gardens and fish market that we planned to visit and convenient for countless shops and restaurants plus Tokyo Station for the fast cross country trains. Most things were within flat walking distance but there were two different metro lines just outside the hotel entrance.The staff were welcoming and extremely helpful and the room was of a good size but very well equipped all round, all mod cons, especially in the loo!The reception area was simple but chic and the price was reasonable. All round this is a great launchpad for a trip around Japan.

the hotel is located in the ginza quarter of the city. the location is very central. the hotel is close to the subway and only two subway stops away from the tokyo station.the room abd the bed was very big for tokyo. everything was very clean and the personal was very friendly.this hotel is a perfect place for a short visit of tokyo.

We arrived here after a long morning of travel and were thrilled to be allowed into our room early. Very much appreciated!The design of the building is great, looks awesome!Room was super clean, and there was enough room. Everything was modern and it looked great. Loved the bathroom, especially the bath!Excellent location, there is a subway station literally outside the hotel front door, and another about two minute's walk away.Hotel is right in the heart of Ginza, great for shopping and eating.Perfect hotel, would definitely return!

Close to two subway lines, just across the street from supermarket, new hotel (2014), very good and diverse (Japanese and European) breakfast. Beautiful room. Reception staff was amazing! Plenty of restaurants in the area.

1. is very good and close to main shopping district and metro stations2. Clean hotel and very organised3. Breakfast was good but need more variety of cheese and bread.4. Staff are wonderful and helpful. Ask the concierge for any help

We recently stayed at this hotel and it was a great base for our holiday in Tokyo. The tube station is right at the doorstop. Its also possible to walk to Tokyo station in around 20 minutes. The rooms are extremely well appointed and make good use of the space. Everything is finished off to a high standard. The room was cleaned on a daily basis and a newspaper left every morning. Check in is 3 pm which is clearly stated. We arrived a bit earlier (around 11am) due to our flight times but the reception kept our luggage and although tired, it gave us a chance to look around the area and check out some of the many cafes in the area. Japan is an amazing place to have a holiday and this hotel was the perfect base.

Thumb up to hotel's location as it is very very closed to tube station. I really enjoy stay in Ginza area as it is surrounded by interesting cafes and restaurants. Also, Ginza area is much less noisy and crowded than Shinjuku or Harajugu is.The hotel is quite new. Bedroom is very clean and bathroom is proportionally big.Another strength of this hotel is that it is convenient to catch Airport bus. That is, walking about 2 blocks to Marriott Courtyard Hotel, where the airport bus station located.

A modern hotel with every space in the room very well thought out in view of the fact that hotel rooms are invariably smaller in Japan. Nice colour décor using earth colours. Staff at reception friendly and there is a restaurant downstairs open until midnight.

Excellent location to shop in Ginza and see the fish market Hotel rooms are modern, clean and new. Small rooms.The reception area always crowded with people.No room service or gym. Buffet breakfast was terrible staff can't speak English and food is not for western eating.

Fabulous hotel centrally located and with metro lift right outside the door. We had a room with a window (some are internal), and whilst it was small, it was very comfortable and so well planned that we didn't feel the size. Great restaurant downstairs, helpful staff, and very close to the main shopping street in Ginza. We would stay again in a flash!

Will stay in this hotel if I decide to go back to Tokyo. It is located in Ginza and has a station right very close to the hotel.Room was comfortable after long walks around Tokyo. Would have wanted to have more international TV stations though.

i love the location of this hotel, but i am giving only 3 points because of the front desk service. unfortunately it was pretty terrible. the staff had a very poor knowledge of English and they were not able to help me when i approached them asking for suggestions and directions. this is to something they should change because this is a 4 star hotel, in the middle of Tokyo, in a very touristy area, so you would think the personal is prepared to help the international guests at least with basic communication. other than that, breakfast is great, rooms are clean and new.and again location is perfect. near ginza metro station, easy to reach every area and main attraction. especially good for shopping!

Although the room was very small and felt like a closet, this hotel has everything you need for visiting Tokyo and especially the Ginza area. The staff were very helpful although the level of language skills vary quite significant from each receptionist.The style of the hotel is very nice in minimalistic Japanese style.Its located right in the centre of everything. 10 mins by foot to the Fish Market.
