Brighton and Hove, United Kingdom

review_body: This is a top location; across the street from the traditional theater (where the man with white painted faced perform plays in traditional clothes), and walking distance from the famous fish market. In between many shops, too!The hotel is ultra modern, with all amenities you would like. And of course the ever-attentive service of Japan. We had a triple room in the corner of the building, so great views. Very comfortable beds, and the nicest pijamas I ever received around the world (unfortunately not for sale). The toilet is another miracle of Japanese technology, a class above the ones you find everywhere in Japan.Warmly recommended.

A new hotel with all the new furniture and facilities. The location is great, next to the exit of subway and close to all nice shops and restaurants. Though the room is small, we like the Toto washlet, new electrical pot, etc. The only flaw is the hard mattress, especially when the hotel doesn't supply any extra soft foam, as some great hotels do. The most impressive is their service. When we came in on a rainy day, the doorgirl wiped the water off our coats. When we offered tips for the doorman who got our luggage and a taxi for us, he didn't take it with dignity. We truly admire their service attitude.

We arrived late on a Monday night and were booked into a corner room. Check in clerk was a little off hand. No porterage, (but maybe that's normal). Found our room, and a notice on the desk that there was the possibility of construction noise from the next door building, which was rather annoying, as nothing had been mentioned about it at the time of booking, or by the front desk. As it was late, we showered, went out for a bite and to bed early. The next morning there was a slightly but nonetheless sufficiently irritating noise emanating from the building next door. I immediately rang the front desk and asked to speak to the duty manager. Mr Ichikawa rang back and apologised and offered to move us to the other side of the building. In addition, he upgraded us to a deluxe twin room. I was impressed by his attentiveness and willingness to rectify the situation. Thereafter we enjoyed the peace and quiet of this excellently located hotel, in the heart of Ginza, with its excellent subway links. The dining facilities are limited, but we had amuse bouche and drinks in the bar one evening and they were good. As noted by other guests, rooms are small, in line with Tokyo standards, so it was a huge help to have the upgrade. The room facilities are of top quality Japanese precision - bathroom/wet room and "washlet". Prices are currently very good with the weak yen and the promotional rates. Apart from the initial off handed behaviour of the check in clerk, staff were otherwise very polite in the usual Japanese style, which is always a delight.

The locatation was fantastic! Right in the heart of Ginza and walking distance to Tsukiji fish market. Many shops and eateries near the hotel.The subway stop is just out the front door.Rooms were comfortable and hotel staff friendly and accomodating. Would definitely stay here again!

We stayed for 3 nights in a double room. Rooms are small by western standards but quite big for Japan. The hotel is in a fantastic location right in the heart of Ginza with easy access to both Ginza and Higashi-Ginza metro stations. The bathroom was fabulous with dual heads and a massive bath - the separate toilet was a bonus (just remember to keep the door closed or the toilet lid will open everytime you go by). My only criticism would be the air conditioning - we couldn't seem to get the temperature right - the room was so hot when we arrived we had to resort to putting the air conditioning onto summer mode (in winter) - which was then freezing.

The Millennium Mitsui is a fantastic hotel. Brand new with excellent design, facilities, and service. The location is perfect for exploring all districts of Tokyo; right in the heart of Ginza. The staff speaks great English by Tokyo hotel standards. Being from the states, we thought about playing it safe and going for a Westin or some other dependable brand but we are definitely glad we didn't. Concierge great for recommendations and directions. Note: the rooms are smaller than most hotels in Tokyo at this price point but in exchange you get a brand-new and well located hotel at a great price. The rooms are quite small but are very functional and efficient. Free in-room WiFi ( a rarity in Tokyo). Also a great breakfast. Highly reccomend

review_body: Good pointsVery newClean rooms.Small but room layout was functional and convenientStaff very helpful, polite, excellent customet serviceExcellent location in GinzaVery near shopping districtTrain station is just acrossRestaurants nearbyIppudoMitsukoshi food hallNearest airport limousine stop is courtyard mariott ginza. Very short walkValue for money hotel in ginza

A new hotel with excellent facilities and great transport connections. Aesthetically pleasing decor in the lobby and in the rooms. Wi-fi is free. Rooms are a little small but with top of the range bathroom facilities (typical of Japan :) ). I can see in some reviews people are bothered by the toilet seat cover opening and closing automatically--- just close the sliding door if the toilet's not in use. Reception staff are extremely pleasant (special mention to Ms. Shimizu for her patience and assistance) with the exception of some (which may be due to limited English). Walking distance to Tsukiji market and the main Ginza shopping strip. A 24 hour Donki store is 10 min walk away which sells souvenirs and anything you can possibly think of! Higashi-Ginza station of the Tokyo Metro lines is right in front of the hotel. JR pass users beware, this is not included in your JR pass--you'll need to walk to Yukaracho or Tokyo station to use it. If you would like to have dinner in the surrounding areas, Tsukiji Sushi sen is a stone's throw away or if you're after something interesting, Ginza Isomura has a few outlets around the area but be sure to make a reservation! An all round satisfactory experience.

I have been here for a business trip and really enjoy the place. Great staff,clean room with enough amenities and ok size for a short staying. Location is great and rooms are quite. I recommend to ask for rooms not facing the main road due to some costruction and high traffic which may disturb. Price is slightly lower than other hotel in the area. I have not tried breakfast. Free wifi. A great selection of resturant in short walking distance. The metro station is facing the hotel. The overall impression is really good. With reasonable prices it could be a good place to stay in Tokyo.

This hotel is in great location. It's only few minutes walk to the main shopping area in Ginza and the Tsukiji market for seafood. The metro station is just next to the hotel. The room was quite small but with smart design. You would get most of the things you need. The bed was very good. We had a good sleep there. Service was very attentive as well.

i heard this hotel just opened about 3 months ago so was eager to try it. but the service is bad...slow and they have poor attitude. usually, service is good in japan. also, my room was not properly cleaned. they did not clean out previous guests stuff. also, the toilet seat kept going up and down on its own in the middle of the night...which caused noise and is disturbing.location is not bad...though too expensive for this kind of service. wifi is ok...not the fastest but works for the most part.

My family and I stayed for 3 days here -- and we all agreed that we should have booked and stayed longer! ALL staff were very friendly and accommodating. We had an easy and quick check in (and check out). They were very helpful and attentive for any concern that we had. Special mention to Mr. Itakura who always have a big and warm smile on his face :) He even had a small welcoming treat for my son! Rooms are modern, big for Japanese standards, very comfortable bed and pillows, clean, crisp, neat! Not to mention their "techie" toilet :) Great and big HD TV, humidifier, and all basic things were provided for. Location is great -- within the heart of shopping district, and near everything that Tokyo is known for!! There"s a minute walk to Higanshi ginza train station on the hotel's right side, and for those who have JR Passes like us, the JR Yamanote Yurakucho Station is a mere 5-10 minutes walk. Another plus point: they have their own automated foreign exchange machine (for USD, CNY,GBP, EUR,AUD, SGD, KRW,TWD near the elevators! :)It's a great tokyo hotel! Will definitely go back!

Location of hotel is in the heart of Ginza, situated right above Higashi-Ginza station making it very convenient and easily accesible. Rooms are new as this hotel is relatively new, but the housekeeping is not very good. Staffs are not very friendly and their knowledge of the area around Tokyo is not sufficient, every time when they were asked a question, they would need to take a long time to search for the information.

The Millennium Mitsui Garden Hotel Tokyo is a great choice for single travelers who want a great location, a fresh, modern room and a comfortable bed. I stayed for six nights in this hotel, and I was very happy with the stay AFTER I adjusted my expectations.I had a Superior Double room (215 square feet / 20 square meters). Yes, this may be a Tokyo standard room size, but a good amount of the room is taken up by the bathroom and toilet (more later). Additionally, while there is space to hang clothes (and a shelf above), there is only ONE small drawer in the room to store clothes. Thus, I had to use the space in front of the tiny, single-seat couch to house my suitcase. I used my suitcase as my clothing storage space. Not good. There is AMPLE room below the desk to have put a set of storage drawers; there's no reason why they could not have made the room more appropriate for travelers.Okay, on to the room amenities:- I stated that much of the room was taken by the bath / separate toilet (top of the line Toto). However, this was not a bad thing after all. The shower is superb with both a rainfall shower head and a hand-held unit. The walk-in shower also had an accompanying ofuro (deep soaking) tub, Japanese style. Lovely. There was ample room in the shower/bath and it was a luxurious space. Loved it.- Separate toilet with soft-close sliding door. And an automatic toilet seat, Toto washlet...nice. Be sure to close the door when the toilet is not in use or every time you walk by, the lid will rise and beep. :-)- Large fridge with two complimentary bottles of water (EACH day). Yes, you can go buy your own drinks and snacks and not have the "touch it and buy it" experience like some Japanese hotels. This was great.- Bed. Very comfy with a down duvet. Comfy and clean.- Blackout curtain. REALLY important.- Soundproofed. The rooms are REALLY well soundproofed. I barely heard any noise at all.- Hot pot. Instead of a coffee maker, the room was equipped with a hot pot, coffee (single-serve drip bags), tea, etc. It was a nice set-up.- Shiseido skincare products. NICE!- Hair dryer, "throw away" slippers, and (oddly) pajamas. No robe??? - Great HD TV. And, as a bonus, the ability to watch one or two channels in English (just keep hitting some buttons on the remote to toggle through the language broadcasts). - Humidifier. Yup! Nice touch, especially in winter!- Climate control system. It would have been nice if the English translations to the controls were in the room instructions like they were for the humidifier. :-)- In-room safe. While nice to have, it was awkwardly placed in a drawer under the hanging rack for the clothes. Um, it's not bolted down. So, it's not really a safe, is it...? Someone could ostensibly just unhook the drawer and take the safe. - Iron and ironing board.- English newspaper every morning. - Free Wi-Fi throughout the hotel. It was best to connect in the lobby and then re-connect in the room. The throughput was FAIR. FaceTime video was choppy, but audio was fine.Service- Front desk. Very friendly. Limited English, but enough to get by.- Maid service. Varied. Some days, the room was spotless. Others...not so much. Oh well.- Restaurant. Not great. The restaurant service was the WEAKEST part of this property. The meals were all buffet style, although there were some ala carte items that you could order. The service was odd, spotty and not very "Japanese." The servers were all over the place, yet they rarely checked on tables/diners. When I went to the lunch buffet, some of the chafing dishes were empty for a long period. The cocktail service...let's just say that Martinis should NOT be yellow!!! I was very disappointed in the pricey restaurant and lackluster service, but I must say that the food was good.LocationOne of the best parts of this hotel was the location. A few steps (or elevator trip) to the Higashi Ginza metro station and the Ginza metro station OR a few blocks to the JR Yamanote line (Yurakucho station) made this a wonderful central location. Mitsukoshi is only half a block away (go check out the basement food floors, the adjacent Laduree macaron shop and the 8th floor artisan crafts showcase). Designer shops are everywhere, along with local gems (check out the tiny kimono fabric shop on the corner, Itoya stationery store a few blocks away, the hobby shop on the block with Sashiko kits...oh...it was a shopper's paradise). The food around the area skewed towards lunch/dinner, with a great Ramen street just a block or two away (ate at the Duck Ramen place and it was FABULOUS).When I return to Tokyo, I'd definitely consider staying here again. It's well-priced / a good value for the area. The rooms are small but comfortable and efficient. The staff (except for the restaurant) is great. Oh, there is construction going on right next door. Ask for a room away from the construction.

I stayed there for 4 nights. The hotel is very clean and the staff are polite. They have a decent command of English and are always willing to help. The location is fantastic. It is located near highs higashi-Ginza metro line. Use the A1 exit. There is a lift that will bring u to the first floor of the hotel. will come back again.

This hotel was the best surprise of our trip to Japan.We stayed here for a total of four nights (two nights on our way to our skiing trip to Shiga Kogen and two nights on our way back) and we felt it was practically impossible to find a defect in this brand new establishment. Each time check-in and check-out have been lightning fast.The rooms are modern, well designed and appointed, impeccably clean, quiet, with a bright large window (with black out curtain for those who don't want light in the room early in the morning) , a nice view and every amenity one may need. The rooms are also quite big by Japanese standards and there was enough space to move around with two large suitcases (we are a family of three with a 6 years old boy). Everything was in perfect working order and the wifi was excellent.The location is very good (just 2 minutes walk from the Ginza and the Higashi Ginza lines).Breakfast (not included) was excellent: a varied buffet with fresh fruit juice, a leg of 'jamon' sliced in front of you, and a good selection of western and Japanese foods.The staff were all extremely helpful and went out of their way to help us and satisfy our every need (my wife unfortunately needed an x ray for a skiing injury and the reception staff organized everything efficiently and effectively).The only minor downside is that at times a good number of staff on duty are trainees and with slightly weaker English skills. But they do try their best and they manage to get the job done in any case.In summary we would highly recommend this hotel with no hesitation to both business and leisure travellers, including families.

Let me begin by saying that this is simply the best hotel that I have ever stayed at in Japan.THE LOCATIONA direct train from Haneda Airport to Higashi-Ginza station was the first pleasant surprise, but even better was finding that both Higahi-Ginza and Ginza subway stations had entrances on the same block as the hotel. This gives access to the Ginza, Marunouchi, Asakusa and Hibiya lines. JR Yurakucho Station is about a ten minute walk if you want the Yamanote line.Mitsukoshi department store is across the road, with an excellent food hall underneath, even if you can't afford the clothing. Uniqlo is around the corner to top up on any basics you might need.The streets west of the main road have a lot of luxury shopping and upmarket bars and restaurants, while the eastern side has cheaper and cosier dining and drinking.THE FRONT OF HOUSEOne is greeted by a veritable battalion of staff at check-in, some of whose job seems to be primarily to bow, greet you, hold the elevator, and generally make you feel welcome. I was helped with my bags up to my room (a rarity in Japan), and whenever it was raining outside, there were plenty of staff on hand to furnish an umbrella.My heart sank a little when I realised that my room (top floor, as per my emailed request) faced directly towards neighbouring construction works, and a note suggested that night works were anticipated. However, a quick request had me shifted to the other side of the building, with profuse apologies that the only available room for the full duration of my two-week stay was only on the second-to-top floor. Needless to say, I didn't mind in the slightest. The same pleasant gentleman helped me with my bags again, and I settled in.THE ROOMThe room itself was superb, large by Japanese standards, and with clever design features that made it seem larger. As you will see from the professional pictures, there is an entire small room dedicated as a shower/bath, with opaque frosted glass walls, so that it's not too claustrophobic. If you are using the shower. The separate toilet next to the bathroom comes with a top-of-the-line Toto washlet, although I do question using a frosted glass partition, rather than a solid wall between the two.A large sink and mirror then sits in the main part of the room, next to the hanger racks. What this meant is that I could shave while my partner showered, or she could do her makeup while I took a bath. This really improved the utility of the room and made us a lot more efficient in the morning.Finally, the bed was extremely comfortable. The small padded bench next to the bed was too short to comfortably sit on, so we ended up using it for bags, and sitting on the bed or at the desk most of the time. Other hotels where an armchair is provided have the slight edge here, but it's a minor gripe.One more tiny complaint (well, I did say *almost* flawless) is the lack of a laundry room. There is a laundry service, but it is typically expensive. I ended up washing my socks, underwear, and thermals in the sink and hanging them on the racks in the bathroom overnight, and this worked pretty well.

Before I review the hotel itself, I would like to say that the service was exceptional. From the front desk, to the person greeting us at the front, and to the person making sure we got on the elevator, the hospitality in this hotel just can't be beat. That being said, the hotel is in a fantastic location in the Ginza district, about a block or two from the Ginza subway stop (there are 2 different lines that connect). It is a short walk to all the shopping, and about 25-30 minutes walk (well, as New Yorkers, we tend to speed-walk) to the Imperial Palace. The Ginza district has some pretty trendy restaurants, and the first Starbucks in Japan is a little ways across the street. The hotel is also relatively close to Tokyo train station, which is where we took the airport express train, then cab both to and from the hotel to the station. The rooms were on the smaller size, but smartly arranged, and it was comfortable. No complaints except some construction in the early mornings- it was a great location, clean, and great for the money paid. Will definitely stay here again.

review_body: Stayed 3 night last week for business trip. Location so nice. Room and reaaurant also good. But staffs of Lobby are too unkind. No smile. Ignore us. I never saw that unkind staff in Japan . So really surprise. But staff of restaurant and housekeeping reall kind and warm.Location and room and restsursnt nice. But staff of lobby too bad.

I was really pleased with this brand-new hotel in a fantastically well positioned part of Tokyo. The value for what we got was fantastic. Good size rooms, huge windows, extraordinary state of art automatic bathrooms and great staff. Walking distance to the fish markets and to all the Ginza Department stores. The only thing missing was an Onsen.

I stayed here for 7 nights recently with my older children and was most impressed. The staff were all friendly, helpful and professional. The front desk staff were welcoming and did their very best to accommodate our needs. The housekeeping staff did an exceptional job with all rooms being impeccably clean and comfortable. The beds are extremely comfortable. The hotel is quiet and in a great location within minutes walk to shopping, a variety of restaurants and two train stations. I would definitely stay here again

This brand new hotel has an excellent location about 100m from the centre of the Ginza area in central Tokyo. It is very close to various subway lines and a 5 minute taxi ride to Tokyo station. Our double room was smart, well equipped and modern, although fairly small. The onsite restaurant is very good and the staff are very friendly and helpful with sufficient English to make life easy. The area is surrounded by shops large and small and countless places to eat. The subway lines can get you to key tourist sights in Tokyo very efficiently. We really enjoyed our stay. We paid Y20,000 a night but did book rather late. Would definitely stay here again.

This is a new hotel only opened end of 2014. From the moment we entered the hotel lobby we we afforded every courtesy possible. The lobby staff and those behind the desk went to every effort to assist us with directions and extra bookings. The hotel is located in the shopping area and is well serviced by public transport with on railway station outside the front door and another a very short walk. There are many local restaurants and some western ones near by. Recommend breakfast in the hotel. If I a hurry there is a Starbucks a short walk away. I would stay here anytime I am in Tokyo.

I used to stay in Mitsui Garden Hotel Ginza Premier for couple of times. However, this time I decided to try out this brand new hotel (opened in Dec 2014) from the same Mitsui Garden chain. I have to say I will sure stay in this hotel from now on whenever I will visit Tokyo again.Why? The location speaks itself. It is far more convenient than Mitsui Garden Ginza Premier which is located between Ginza and Shimbashi (whichever way you have to walk at least 7 minutes to the station). On the contrary, Millennium is located right on top of the subway station Higashi Ginza (A1 exit). More important of all, if you fly in/out Tokyo via the Haneda Airport, there is a Keikyu airport line directly run from Haneda to Higashi Ginza and only takes about 24 minutes and no need to change transport in between. There is also a elevator for A1 exit and you don't even need to cross a road with your luggage to get to the hotel.Beside easy transfer to/from airport, the hotel is located at the center of Ginza. The department stores and restaurants are just next door. Perfect - if you are shopaholic, you don't even need to get outside of Ginza and spend days shopping in the Ginza/Yurakucho area. The most famous restaurants are also around you in this renowned prestigious area of Tokyo.Back to the hotel itself, firstly you are greeted by a pretty and huge lobby with a huge LED backdrop that keeps changing color (PRETTY!) Staff service is excellent and professional without complaints. Our room is facing the Mitsukoshi department store (yah, it's just opposite to Mitsukoshi). Twin room size is not too small and quite acceptable. The best thing is the layout design with separate shower, toilet and washing basin area. It is very convenient. Wifi is also very stable and fast. Another plus is daily supply of two complimentary water bottles.Ah - the only downside is the noise at night from the cars downstairs. However, what do you expect for a hotel located right at the busiest part of the city?A little tip: If you have big luggage and want to take elevator when go to Haneda airport from hotel, please remember to use the exit next to Kabukicho. The elevator for A1 exit does not get you to the Haneda Airport platform unless you do not mind carrying it using the steps.

We stayed at the Mitsui Garden Hotel for 17 nights over the 2014-2015 Christmas/New Year period. The staff were wonderful and very accommodating. We would often leave the hotel quite late, but would always find our room made up and fresh towels waiting for us when we returned. The location in Ginza is perfect, so close to so many different subway lines... couldn't ask for much more! Would definitely stay here again, highly recommended.

Visited Tokyo last weekend and we stayed at this new hotel. We were a little worried when we booked this hotel because it wasnt even opened when we booked it, but we are very glad the hotel turned out very nice and comfortable. Location is within 2 min walk to Ginza Station. Most importantly, its only 10 mins walk to the Tsujiki market! We manage to visit Tsukiji market twice this trip because its so convenient! Staff had been very helpful with helping us book restaurants. Rooms are comfortable and the size is very reasonable.

Myself and boyfriend booked here for then end of our skiing trip as a base to explore Tokyo for 2 days.We were impressed.In an upmarket area and the hotel itself looks very upmarket as well!We had a double room with a great city view.Clean and warm in the hotel room.Had a separate toilet and bathroom area.Bathroom had a bath tub and shower so great to relax in.There was a TV and complimentary water, shampoo, conditioner, body wash, toothbrush, hairbrush- there was even pyjamas and slippers for your stay.When we arrived there was a note in our room saying construction would be occurring till March every night from 9pm until 6am- but both nights we heard nothing and had a great night sleep.Also the JR pass station Yurakucho is an easy walk- the site says 10 mins but I don't think it took us that long.Worth the money you pay.

This is a nice hotel that I booked online. Clean, tidy, firm bed, new deco, complete amenities, nice lighting in the room. Good location in Ginza. I like Ginza because it's not so crowded. Every where you can find food & good for shopping too.

Brand new hotel. Clean, modern, comfortable,great location, hugely attentive staff with good English. Very well priced for all that and location. I've stayed many hotels in Tokyo in last three years, this outstrips then all, but a country mile.

It's near the heart of Ginza, so excellent location. We were booked in a "superior double room." It was definitely more spacious than any of the standard businessmen hotels in which we had been staying. There was enough floor space for us to open three suitcases and repack for our return flight. The washroom layout is very smart: toilet, shower/tub, and sink/mirror stations all independent so one person won't tie up the bathroom. I will stay here again. Tip: If you have heavy luggage and need to use an elevator, you must walk over from/back to Ginza subway station (about 2 blocks). The elevator right in front of the hotel takes you to a subway entrance but it has no elevator to the platform.

Excellent gem right on Ginza. What more to say? :-) Very close to the subway train lines. There's one directly outside the hotel and which can get you straight (limited express train) to Haneda Airport. Superb location. Hotel is basic but functional. Room is not big (standard size for Japan) but has very nice layout so you don't feel cramped. Anyway with the shopping and entertainment belt just walking distance away, I was mostly out of the hotel. And then back for a quick charge before heading out again. So convenient.

We only spend a night at this hotel on route to Hakuba for our skiing holiday. The hotel is brand new, just opened in late December. The staff at the reception speaks good English, and the rooms are well equipped with comfy bed. I like the extra touches, Pyjamas, toothbrush, comb, etc. I haven't seen these in hotels in Australia for a while now! Location is central in Ginza, so convenient for visiting central Tokyo, there is a metro just outside the hotel, and the Rail station is 10 minutes walk away. Overall, this is very satisfactory and I will stay here again.

Stayed for 4 nights, everything was great. The room was great, everything was there. The staff is great, speaks good English. Location is near the metro exit n opposite is a great ramen Plc, two in fact. Will be back if I ever come to Tokyo againFrom 1st to 5thjan we stayed there .

This hotel opened less than a week ago when I checked in. When I booked, only "artist impressions" (drawings) were available, no photos. So I felt a little unsure about it all. But the price seemed right as did the location.As to the location: it is just about perfect. The hotel is located in one of the two major streets of the Ginza shopping area. Even better: it sits right on top of a subway station (Higashi Ginza), which makes this hotel suitable for day trips as well. The famous Mitsukoshi department store is right accross the street.The lobby looks spacious and very modem. Checkin was quick and curious. The room (#1001) is again very modern looking and the size is fair for a Japanese hotel room. Since the hotel just opened I was likely the first or second guest ever in the room, so it was spotlessly clean.Despite its modest size, the room is equipped with a huge television, a big bed, a shower (both rain shower and hand held), a bath (full size), a separate toilet, a safe deposit box, an iron and ironing board and a sophisticated air cleaner/humidifier. The bed is reasonably soft, not the Japanese rock hard kind.Minor complaints are the limited number of towels provided and the fact that room cleaning took my (empty) water bottles. I tend to re-fill those, so now I had to buy new bottles every day.My single big complaint is about the buffet style restaurant in the basement; it has zero vegetarian options. Even the sauces are meat based, so I could literally eat nothing there. Since this hotel is mainly aimed at guests from overseas I experienced this as really inhospitable and inconsiderate. On the other hand: Ginza offers lots of great restaurants and they were happy to serve vegetarian dishes. In conclusion: one day after opening the M hotel leaves a good impression.
